questions.text: Which of the following is not a common boundary between Calot's triangle and the Hepatocystic triangle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystic artery Calot's triangle - Boundaries: Inferior- cystic duct and GB Medial- common hepatic duct Above- Cystic artery Hepatocystic triangle - Boundaries Inferior- Cystic duct and GB Medial- Common hepatic duct Above- Inferior surface of Liver

Highyeild:

Calot's triangle: This triangle is located in the region of the gall bladder and is bordered superiorly by the cystic artery, medially by the common hepatic duct, and laterally by the cystic duct. Hepatocystic triangle: This triangle is also located in the region of the Gall bladder and is bordered superiorly by the inferior surface of the liver, medially by the common hepatic duct, and laterally by the cystic duct. Femoral triangle: This triangle is located in the thigh and is bordered superiorly by the inguinal ligament, medially by the medial border of the adductor longus muscle, and laterally by the medial border of the sartorius muscle. The femoral artery pulsations can be felt in this region.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & C. All of these are present as the common boundary between Calot's triangle and the Hepatocystic triangle

questions.text: True about Mirizzi syndrome

options.label: A
options.text: Any inflammatory process involving the gall bladder and cystic duct can secondarily inflame the common bile duct, causing an obstruction.

options.label: B
options.text: A large stone in a Hartmann pouch can compress

options.label: C
options.text: Cholecystocholedochal fistula may or may not be apparent

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Biliary Strictures may occur in the middle portion of the common duct and are frequently associated with a process in the gall bladder. Any inflammatory process involving the gall bladder and cystic duct can secondarily inflame the common bile duct, causing an obstruction. Alternatively, a large stone in the Hartmann pouch can compress the adjacent bile duct and cause an apparent stricture. Both of these fall under the diagnosis of Mirizzi syndrome. Obstruction of the bile duct from an inflammatory process is the hallmark of this syndrome; the cholecystocholedochal fistula may or may not be apparent. IOC: MRCP.

Highyeild:

Mirizzi's Syndrome(Functional Hepatic Syndrome) Mirizzi's Syndrome is a condition characterized by obstruction of the common hepatic duct or CBD . The obstruction is caused by external compression or erosion of a stone in the Hartmann pouch or cystic duct. Mirizzi's Syndrome is classified into type 1 and type 2 , based on the cause of the obstruction by McSherry . Csendes subclassified Type 2 into three categories based on the percentage of the CBD wall eroded by the offending calculus.

Extraedge:

Csendes Classification of Mirizzi's Syndrome Type I Obstruction of the common duct due to external compression only (no erosion) Type II Erosion of less than one-third of the circumference of the common duct Type III Erosion of up to two-thirds of the circumference of the common duct Type IV Total or near-total circumferential destruction of the common duct Type V Erosion of the Gall bladder in the common duct with a cholecystoenteric fistula Stenosis (narrowing) of the biliary tree often resolves on its own after the surgical procedure, and therefore choledochotomy (incision of the common bile duct) is rarely necessary.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old woman comes to the emergency department with complaints of a 10-hour history of severe nausea and abdominal pain that began 30 minutes after eating dinner. The pain primarily is in her right upper quadrant and occasionally radiates to her back. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. Her BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/76 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness with guarding. A bedside ultrasound shows a gall bladder wall measuring 6 mm, pericholecystic fluid, sloughing of the intraluminal membrane, and a 2 x 2 cm stone at the neck of the gall bladder. The common bile duct appears unremarkable. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and normal liver function tests. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: CT of the abdomen with contrast

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibiotic therapy The patient's findings are suggestive of acute calculous cholecystitis. Ultrasound evidence of acute calculous cholecystitis (ACC) in this patient with signs of systemic infection (fever of 38.8°C) and a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus warrant prompt initiation of empiric antibiotic therapy . Antibiotic therapy should be targeted against the pathogens most commonly causing ACC, including gram-negative rods and anaerobes. For patients with community-acquired ACC, intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam is an appropriate choice. After initiation of antibiotic therapy, a laparoscopic cholecystectomy should be performed within 2–3 days.

Highyeild:

Acute Cholecystitis: Related to gallstones in 90-95% of cases Characterized by RUQ pain, fever, and leukocytosis The initial event is obstruction of the cystic duct leading to biliary colic The inflammatory process with thickened and reddish wall with subserosal haemorrhage RUQ pain is the most common symptom, along with fever and nausea/vomiting Diagnosis through USG and HIDA scan Treatment includes IV fluids, antibiotics, and analgesia , followed by cholecystectomy (preferably laparoscopic) within 2-3 days of presentation.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Ursodeoxycholic acid may be used to dissolve small, non-calcified cholesterol gallstones in poor surgical candidates with mildly symptomatic but uncomplicated cholelithiasis. This patient, however, does not have any comorbidities or risk factors that would make her a poor candidate for surgery (e.g., age > 80 years). Moreover, this patient has gallstone disease complicated by acute cholecystitis, which requires a different treatment approach. Option: B. In a patient with right upper quadrant pain, a contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen would be the next best step if the patient's ultrasound was inconclusive (e.g., gallstones or biliary sludge on ultrasound but no evidence of gall bladder inflammation). This is done to confirm the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis as well as to rule out other conditions that may occasionally mimic acute cholecystitis (e.g., pancreatitis, perforated peptic ulcer). This patient has ample evidence of acute calculous cholecystitis on ultrasound, meaning that a different step is indicated. Option: C. In a patient with evidence of acute calculous cholecystitis on ultrasound, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography would be the next best step only if a common bile duct stone were visualized. This patient's common bile duct appears normal on ultrasound, and therefore ERCP would not be indicated at this time.

Extraedge:

Bile acids CDCA and UDCA Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase , decreasing cholesterol saturation of bile Causes dispersion of cholesterol from stones by physicochemical means Prerequisites for treatment include radiolucent stones, stones <10 mm in diameter, and functioning GB Drawbacks include low rates of complete resolution, high recurrence rate, and need for maintenance therapy to prevent a recurrence

questions.text: 12 days after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis, a 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of persistent episodic epigastric pain for 3 days. The pain radiates to her back, occurs randomly throughout the day, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. Each episode lasts 30 minutes to one hour. Antacids do not improve her symptoms. She has hypertension and fibromyalgia. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6° F), her pulse is 84/min, her respirations are 14/min, and her blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the upper quadrants without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. The incisions are clean, dry, and intact. Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the common bile duct and no gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Serum studies show: AST 80 U/L ALT 95 U/L Alkaline phosphatase 213 U/L Bilirubin, total 1.3 mg/dL Direct 0.7 mg/dL Amylase 52 U/L
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangio pancreaticography Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction (SOD) Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction (SOD) is a medical condition characterized by pain similar to biliary colic, normal liver function tests, and episodes of acute pancreatitis. The pathogenesis of SOD is unclear, and theories suggest gallstone migration, trauma, pancreatitis, and congenital anomalies as possible causes. The Biliary Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction is classified using th e Modified Milwaukee classification , which divides it into Sphincter of Oddi Stenosis and Sphincter of Oddi Dyskinesis. The Sphincter of Oddi Stenosis, also known as papillitis , is a benign intrinsic obstruction of the common bile duct outlet. Sphincter of Oddi Dyskinesis is an i ntermittent functional blockage of the high-pressure zone of the sphincter, and the basal pressure is elevated. Diagnosis can be made through typical ultrasound findings such as a dilated common bile duct (>12 mm diameter) or an increase in the common bile duct diameter in response to CCK.

Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction (SOD) Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction (SOD) is a medical condition characterized by pain similar to biliary colic, normal liver function tests, and episodes of acute pancreatitis. The pathogenesis of SOD is unclear, and theories suggest gallstone migration, trauma, pancreatitis, and congenital anomalies as possible causes. The Biliary Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction is classified using th e Modified Milwaukee classification , which divides it into Sphincter of Oddi Stenosis and Sphincter of Oddi Dyskinesis. The Sphincter of Oddi Stenosis, also known as papillitis , is a benign intrinsic obstruction of the common bile duct outlet. Sphincter of Oddi Dyskinesis is an i ntermittent functional blockage of the high-pressure zone of the sphincter, and the basal pressure is elevated. Diagnosis can be made through typical ultrasound findings such as a dilated common bile duct (>12 mm diameter) or an increase in the common bile duct diameter in response to CCK.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Some patients may have slight abdominal pain in the first days after cholecystectomy. Patients with only slight pain and no other findings should receive reassurance and follow-up. However, this patient has incapacitating symptoms, elevated cholestatic parameters, and a dilated common bile duct. These findings warrant further investigation and treatment. Option: C. H. pylori stool antigen testing is used to detect infections with H. pylori, which can lead to diseases such as gastritis and PUD. Both conditions can present with upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which are seen in this patient. However, this patient's elevated cholestatic parameters and dilated common bile duct cannot be explained by gastritis or PUD and warrant a different diagnostic approach. Option: D. Proton pump inhibitors can be used to treat GERD, gastritis, or PUD, all of which may present with upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which are seen in this patient. However, GERD, gastritis, or PUD would not explain this patient's elevated cholestatic parameters and dilated common bile duct, which makes these diseases unlikely.

Extraedge:

Endoscopic manometry is considered the gold standard for diagnosis, while the most widely used pharmacologic test to assess sphincter function is the morphine-pyridostigmine provocation test or Nardi Test. The treatment of choice for SOD is Transduodenal sphincteroplasty with transampullary septectomy .

questions.text: A 40-year-old female was diagnosed with cholelithiasis. The following statements are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Cholecystectomy should be performed whenever gallstones are found

options.label: B
options.text: Types of gallstones are cholesterol, pigment and mixed

options.label: C
options.text: Gallstones can cause various complications including intestinal obstruction

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Cholecystectomy should be performed whenever gallstones are found
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholecystectomy should be performed whenever gallstones are found Cholecystectomy is not indicated in all cases of gallstones, the majority of which are asymptomatic. Patients with asymptomatic gallstones should only undergo a cholecystectomy in the following situations: They have a porcelain Gall bladder, which has a high incidence of turning malignant in the long term If they are type 1 diabetics because they are prone to complications If they have a choledochal cyst

Highyeild:

Asymptomatic gallstones do not usually require intervention. Prophylactic cholecystectomy may be performed for asymptomatic cholelithiasis in certain situations Situations, where prophylactic cholecystectomy may be considered, include: Large (>3 cm) gallstones Choledocholithiasis Chronic hemolytic conditions (sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis) Gall bladder polyps >1 cm in diameter Suspicion/risk of malignancy (anomalous pancreatic ductal drainage) Calcification of the wall (porcelain Gall bladder) Some ethnic groups or subjects living in areas with a high prevalence of Gall bladder cancer associated with gallstones Transplant patients (during transplantation) Patients undergoing bariatric surgery For symptomatic gallstones, cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice if there are no medical contraindications Initial non-operative treatment for symptomatic gallstones involves four steps: Nil by mouth and intravenous fluid administration until pain resolves Analgesics Antibiotics (broad-spectrum antibiotics effective against Gram-negative aerobes are preferred) Subsequent management involves reintroducing oral fluids and a regular diet once physical signs of inflammation have subsided.

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Options: B, C & D. All other statements are true.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female has cholelithiasis. She undergoes a cholecystectomy for it. Which of the following statements is true regarding the complications of this surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common bile leak following cholecystectomy is from the cystic duct

options.label: B
options.text: Bile duct injury is usually recognised at the time of the operation

options.label: C
options.text: Stones in the bile ducts are less often associated with infected bile than are stones in the gall bladder

options.label: D
options.text: Jaundice in the postoperative period is usually self-limiting and needs investigating only if it persists for more than 1-week

questions.correct_answer: A. The most common bile leak following cholecystectomy is from the cystic duct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The most common bile leak following cholecystectomy is from the cystic duct

Highyeild:

Complications of cholecystectomy Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is less painful and associated with faster recovery times than open cholecystectomy. Complications can occur in 10-15% of cases, with serious complications falling into two major categories: access complications and bile duct injuries. Bile duct injuries are rare, occurring in approximately 0.5% of laparoscopic cholecystectomy cases, and can result from poor dissection and inadequate definition of surgical anatomy. Operative cholangiography is controversial in terms of reducing the incidence of bile duct injury, and the majority of surgeons use it only in selected cases. Factors that increase the risk of postoperative mortality include advanced age, comorbid conditions, and an acute presentation. Patients who develop jaundice in the postoperative period require urgent investigation, especially if the jaundice is attributed to infection and cholangitis. Urgent ultrasound is the first step in investigating postoperative jaundice, and further imaging (e.g. MRCP or ERCP ) may be required to define the anatomy. Small biliary leaks will usually resolve spontaneously, especially if there is no distal obstruction, but larger leaks or damage to the common bile duct may require expert reconstruction. Drainage catheters may be required to manage fluid collections in the subhepatic space, and these can be inserted under radiological control or, if necessary, at open operation.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Bile-duct injuries 15% of these being recognised at the time of operation in the remaining cases determined postoperatively. Poor dissection and failure to identify the anatomy might contribute to this. Patients who develop jaundice should promptly undergo complete investigations – blood and imaging. Once damage to the CBD is suspected, the patient should be immediately referred to a tertiary hepatobiliary unit. Option: C. Stones in bile ducts are more associated with infected bile than gall bladder stones. Option: D. Jaundice in the postoperative period should be treated promptly.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents as an emergency with sudden onset of severe colicky epigastric pain radiating to the right subcostal region, back and right shoulder tip. The pain makes her feel nauseated and in between attacks, she is left with a dull ache on the right side where she is tender. This has been going on for 48 hours. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary colic Biliary colic occurs in up to one-quarter of patients with gallstones who present as an emergency. It is essentially an obstructive problem, whilst acute cholecystitis is an obstructive problem with superimposed infection.

Highyeild:

Biliary colic presents with sudden onset of severe epigastric pain that radiates to the right subcostal region, back, and right shoulder tip. Biliary colic is caused by the passage of a gallstone through the cystic duct or the common bile duct , leading to obstruction and distention of the Gall bladder or the biliary tree. The pain is thought to be due to the distension of the biliary tree, which stimulates visceral afferent fibres. Diagnosis: Laboratory tests may show an elevation in liver enzymes or bilirubin, but these are typically normal in patients with uncomplicated biliary colic. Imaging studies, such as ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) scans, can confirm the presence of gallstones and may also show evidence of obstruction.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Acute cholecystitis- acute onset of severe right quadrant pain along with nausea and vomiting. Option: C. Carcinoma of Gall bladder patients may be asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis. Symptoms if present is usually indistinguishable from those of benign Gall bladder disease such as biliary colic cholecystitis. Jaundice and anorexia are late features. Option: D. Empyema of the Gall bladder- increasing right upper quadrant pain, swinging pyrexia and extreme tenderness over the Gall bladder. The patient has leucocytosis with raised inflammatory markers; an ultrasound of the Gall bladder shows thickened Gall bladder enveloped by omentum with pericholecystic fluid.

Extraedge:

Management of biliary colic : involves supportive care and symptomatic relief with pain medications and antiemetics . In some cases, cholecystectomy (removal of the Gall bladder) may be necessary to prevent future episodes of biliary colic or complications such as acute cholecystitis or cholangitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female complains of right upper quadrant pain. Her USG was done and an image of her USG gall bladder is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gall bladder stones An ultrasonography of the Gall bladder is shown. Arrows indicate the acoustic shadows from stones in the Gall bladder.

Highyeild:

Ultrasonography is the recommended initial radiologic test for diagnosing acute cholecystitis. Sensitivity and specificity of ultrasonography for diagnosing acute cholecystitis is 70% to 90%. Ultrasonography can effectively detect the presence or absence of stones and show Gall bladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid , which are highly indicative of acute cholecystitis . Sonographic Murphy's sign, e., focal tenderness over the Gall bladder when compressed by the sonographic probe, can further support the diagnosis. Biliary scintigraphy ( HIDA scanning ) can be helpful in atypical cases if the diagnosis remains uncertain after the initial workup. Lack of filling of the Gall bladder after 4 hours on HIDA scan confirms the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis with a sensitivity above 90%. A normal HIDA scan with a clear filling of the Gall bladder rules out the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. CT scans can evaluate multiple potential pathologic processes at once but are slightly less sensitive than ultrasonography for diagnosing acute cholecystitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Empyema of the Gall bladder - increasing right upper quadrant pain, swinging pyrexia and extreme tenderness over the Gall bladder. The patient has leucocytosis with raised inflammatory markers, the Gall bladder is distended with pus, which is not seen in this case Option: C. Acalculous cholecystitis - stones are not seen in this. This is seen in severely ill patients. Option: D. Post-cholecystectomy syndrome - in this patient cholecystectomy is not done

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman complains of intermittent generalised abdominal pain, distension and vomiting for almost 1 week. Over the past couple of days, her pain has become much worse and has been admitted as a surgical emergency. She has gall stones for 2 years. On examination, she is grossly dehydrated. Abdominal examination shows generalised distension and tenderness without any lumps or scars. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gallstone ileus A cholecystoduodenal fistula forms from long-standing chronic cholecystitis, resulting in a gallstone fistulating through into the duodenum. The stone gradually works its way down the small bowel and gets impacted in the narrow terminal ileum causing distal small bowel obstruction. The patient needs to be resuscitated with analgesics, intravenous fluids and nasogastric suction, following which a laparotomy is carried out.

Highyeild:

Gallstone ileus is caused by the passage of a stone through a spontaneous biliary-enteric fistula that leads to mechanical bowel obstruction. The most common site of the fistula is between the Gall bladder and duodenum , while the second most common site is between the Gall bladder and transverse colon . Rigler's triad , which is the classic plain abdominal film triad of small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and ectopic gallstone, is pathognomonic of gallstone ileus. Gallstone ileus occurs most commonly in the elderly ( >70 years ) and accounts for 1% of all cases of small bowel obstruction, occurring in fewer than 1% of patients with gallstones. Bouveret's syndrome is a type of duodenal obstruction caused by gallstones, usually in the bulb, and is treated by duodenostomy or pyloroplasty. The most common site of obstruction in Bouveret's syndrome is the ileum , and pain may be episodic and recurrent as the impacted stone temporarily obstructs the bowel lumen and then dislodges and moves distally, known as tumbling obstruction. Diagnosis of gallstone ileus is done through abdominal X-ray, which shows evidence of intestinal obstruction with pneumobilia or a calcified stone distant from the Gall bladder, and the most common site of obstruction is the terminal ileum.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Empyema of the Gall bladder - increasing right upper quadrant pain, swinging pyrexia and extreme tenderness over the Gall bladder. The patient has leucocytosis with raised inflammatory markers; an ultrasound of the gall bladder shows thickened Gall bladder enveloped by omentum with pericholecystic fluid. Option: C. Acute cholecystitis - acute onset of severe right quadrant pain along with nausea and vomiting. Option: D. Cholecystectomy is not done in this patient.

Extraedge:

Treatment of gallstone ileus is a surgical emergency, with a takedown of the biliary-enteric fistula and cholecystectomy during the same procedure for stable patients, while unstable patients or those with significant inflammation in the right upper quadrant may need a second laparotomy to address the fistula.

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese woman comes to the clinic complaining of intermittent right upper quadrant pain and nausea. She had an elective cholecystectomy for gallstones a year ago. The pain is located in the right subcostal area and generally lasts 30-60 minutes. The patient recalls that she had similar pain episodes before the surgery. Laboratory results after one of the episodes are as follows: An ultrasound of the abdomen reveals mild dilation of the common bile duct. The pancreas is visualized and appears normal. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography This patient's presentation concerns postcholecystectomy syndrome ( PCS ). PCS refers to persistent abdominal pain or dyspepsia (eg, nausea) that occurs either postoperatively (early) or months to years (late) after a cholecystectomy. PCS can be due to biliary (eg, retained common bile duct or cystic duct stone, biliary dyskinesia) or extra-biliary (eg, pancreatitis, peptic ulcer disease, coronary artery disease) causes. Patients usually notice the same pain they had prior to surgery, new pain just after surgery, or the same pain that never went away.

Highyeild:

ERCP is effective in diagnosing choledocholithiasis. Experienced operators can achieve successful cannulation of the ampulla of Vater and diagnostic cholangiography in over 90% of cases. Due to the risks associated with the procedure, ERCP is rarely used as a purely diagnostic modality and is usually reserved for cases where therapeutic intervention is planned. Endoscopic ultrasound is a comparable alternative to ERCP in detecting common bile duct stones, with a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 97%. Endoscopic ultrasound lacks therapeutic capabilities and requires specialized expertise, making it less desirable except in specific clinical scenarios. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) may be performed for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes in rare cases where endoscopic or surgical approaches are contraindicated.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Antimitochondrial antibodies are usually elevated in primary biliary cirrhosis. These patients typically have other symptoms (eg, pruritus, fatigue, jaundice) along with abdominal pain. Although primary biliary cirrhosis can present with laboratory findings similar to those seen in this patient, imaging typically does not show a dilated common bile duct Option: C. Helicobacter pylori stool antigen testing is used for diagnosing H pylori infection in patients with peptic ulcer disease. It is not typically associated with abnormal liver function tests and/or dilated common bile duct. Option: D. Liver biopsy should be done when initial evaluation cannot provide a definitive diagnosis or determine the severity of the liver disease. This patient may require a liver biopsy if ERCP and other laboratory tests are unremarkable.

Extraedge:

ERCP can also collec t bile or pancreatic fluid and brushings from duct strictures to confirm the suspected diagnosis of carcinoma, and brush cytology taken from malignant strictures yields a positive diagnosis in 40-50% of patients. Additionally, ERCP allows for the placement of biliary and pancreatic stents.

questions.text: All the following are associated with an increased risk for cholesterol stone cholelithiasis except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High-protein diet Cholesterol is essentially water-insoluble. Stone formation occurs in the setting of factors that upset cholesterol balance. Obesity, cholesterol-rich diets, high-calorie diets, and certain medications affect the biliary secretion of cholesterol. Intrinsic genetic mutations in certain populations may affect the processing and secretion of cholesterol in the liver.

Highyeild:

Gallstones can be classified as cholesterol, pigment (brown/black), or mixed Cholesterol or mixed stones contain 50-99% pure cholesterol plus calcium salts, bile acids, bile pigments, and Supersaturation of bile with cholesterol and/or low bile acid concentrations can cause unstable phospholipid vesicles to form and nucleate cholesterol crystals. Pigment stones contain less than 30% cholesterol and may be black or brown . Black pigment stones are composed mainly of an insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer mixed with calcium phosphate and calcium bicarbonate. Brown pigment stones contain calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate, and calcium stearate , as well as cholesterol. Brown pigment stones are associated with bile stasis, infection, and foreign bodies in the bile ducts. Removing gallstones without removing the Gall bladder increases the risk of recurrence .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Terminal ileal resection is also associated with gallstone formation, there is no evidence that a high-protein diet confers an added risk of cholelithiasis. Option: C. Oral contraceptive is associated with increased stasis of bile leading to increased risk of cholesterol stone cholelithiasis Option: D. Pregnancy results in both an increase in cholesterol saturation during the third trimester and changes in Gall bladder contractility.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening upper abdominal pain. She reports nausea and vomiting and is unable to tolerate oral intake. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), her pulse is 92/min, her respirations are 18/min, and her blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Examination shows yellowish discolouration of her sclera. Her abdomen is tender in the right upper quadrant. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly. Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts and multiple hyperechoic spheres within the Gall bladder. The pancreas is not well visualized. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole has begun. Twelve hours later, the patient appears acutely ill and is not oriented to time. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), her pulse is 105/min, her respirations are 22/min, and her blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg. Her Lab investigations are mentioned below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography The patient has features suggesting acute cholangitis . Biliary drainage via endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the treatment of choice for acute cholangitis . In mild cases that respond well to antibiotic therapy, ERCP is an elective procedure that takes place 24–48 hours after clinical improvement. In patients who do not respond well to antibiotics or who have severe cholangitis (e.g., signs of sepsis), ERCP should be performed emergently. This patient has mental status changes, tachypnea, tachycardia, and a higher fever and lower blood pressure than on admission despite treatment with ceftriaxone and metronidazole, making her a candidate for immediate ERCP.

Highyeild:

ERCP is effective in diagnosing choledocholithiasis Due to the risks associated with the procedure, ERCP is rarely used as a purely diagnostic modality and is usually reserved for cases where therapeutic intervention is planned. Endoscopic ultrasound is a comparable alternative to ERCP in detecting common bile duct stones, with a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 97%. Endoscopic ultrasound lacks therapeutic capabilities and requires specialized expertise, making it less desirable except in specific clinical scenarios. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography ( PTC ) may be performed for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes in rare cases where endoscopic or surgical approaches are contraindicated.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. An abdominal CT scan could help confirm biliary dilatation and find the cause. However, an urgent intervention should be performed on a patient with cholangitis and biliary dilatation on ultrasound; CT is unnecessary and would delay treatment. Option: B. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy removes the future source of potential gallstones, but it is not a reliable method of removing stones present in the common bile duct. Moreover, surgery is unnecessarily risky in a septic patient when less invasive means of achieving biliary drainage are available. Interval cholecystectomy, usually within 6 weeks, would be indicated in cholangitis associated with gallstones in order to prevent recurrence and complications. Option: C. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography ( MRCP ) is an excellent tool for evaluating pathologies of the biliary tree, e.g., bile duct obstruction. It is, however, a noninvasive imaging study that does not provide biliary drainage. This patient is septic and requires urgent intervention.

Extraedge:

ERCP can also collec t bile or pancreatic fluid and brushings from duct strictures to confirm the suspected diagnosis of carcinoma, and brush cytology taken from malignant strictures yields a positive diagnosis in 40-50% of patients. Additionally, ERCP allows for the placement of biliary and pancreatic stents.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellow discolouration of her skin, loss of appetite, and 3 episodes of vomiting. Her parents also report a darkening of her urine and light stools. During the last 2 days, the girl has been scratching her abdomen and arms and has been crying excessively. She was born at 38 weeks gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of her skin and sclerae. Abdominal examination shows a mass in the right upper abdomen. Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the gall bladder and a fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct. Her Serum Studies are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary cyst The patient has a choledochal cyst. Biliary cysts (or choledochal cysts) are most commonly seen in patients of Asian descent and appear as saccular or fusiform dilations of the biliary tree or as dilated masses that communicate with the biliary tree. A biliary cyst can result in cholestatic jaundice and, if left untreated, increases the risk of cholangitis and cholangiocarcinoma. In rare cases, a biliary cyst may involve the cystic duct and result in gall bladder dilation seen in this patient. The recommended treatment for a biliary cyst is surgical excision of the cyst, followed by the creation of a biliary-enteric anastomosis with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.

Highyeild:

Choledochal cyst A choledochal cyst is a condition characterized by the cystic dilation of the biliary ducts. This condition is more commonly observed in females . It is often associated with biliary atresia , particularly type 1 biliary atresia , and may be detected on antenatal ultrasound. The most widely accepted hypothesis regarding the etiology of choledochal cysts is an abnormal pancreaticobiliary ductal junction (APBDJ) . This results in the reflux of pancreatic fluid into the distal common hepatic duct, causing mucosal injury, chronic inflammation, and weakening of the bile duct wall.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Mirizzi syndrome would result in cholestatic jaundice and dilation of the Gall bladder and extrahepatic bile ducts on ultrasound. However, gallstone disease is rare in children unless risk factors such as chronic hemolytic anaemia (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis) are present. Option: C. Biliary atresia would present with cholestatic jaundice. However, jaundice usually develops within the first few weeks of life, and dilation of the Gall bladder or extrahepatic bile ducts would not be expected. Instead, ultrasound would reveal atresia of the extrahepatic bile ducts and typically a small or absent gall bladder. Option: D. Caroli disease would result in cholestatic jaundice, but the Gall bladder and extrahepatic bile duct would not be dilated on ultrasound. Instead, multiple saccular dilations of the intrahepatic bile ducts could be seen.

Extraedge:

Bile duct cysts are classified based on the site, extent, and shape of the cystic anomaly of the ductal system. The most common type of choledochal cyst is type I , followed by type IV and type III.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of three episodes of severe, sharp, penetrating abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant in 1 hour. During these episodes, she has had nausea and vomiting. She has no diarrhoea, dysuria, or hematuria and is asymptomatic between episodes. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Seven years ago, she underwent resection of the terminal ileum because of severe Crohn's disease. Her BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), her pulse is 80/min, and her blood pressure is 130/95 mm Hg. There is mild scleral icterus. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The stool is brown, and the test for occult blood is negative. Her total Serum Total bilirubin is 4.1 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase is elevated. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a normal liver, a common bile duct calibre of 10 mm (N < 6) and a Gall bladder with multiple gallstones and no wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Choledocholithiasis As indicated by the abdominal ultrasound, this patient has cholelithiasis and dilation of the common bile duct. She probably developed choledocholithiasis as a complication of cholelithiasis. One of the gallstones may have passed into her common bile duct and become stuck there, causing colicky pain and biliary obstruction resulting in elevated levels of bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. Patients with choledocholithiasis develop dark urine and pale stool because bilirubin cannot be secreted via the occluded biliary tract into the intestine, and is excreted via the urine instead. But the change of urine colour may not yet be apparent and the acholic stools may not have passed the bowel yet, explaining the absence of these characteristic symptoms in early-stage biliary obstruction.

Highyeild:

Choledocholithiasis is classified based on the point of origin of CBD stones. It is found in 6-12% of patients with Gall bladder stones. In severe cases of septic shock with toxic cholangitis, ICU monitoring and vasopressors are necessary to support blood pressure. In 15 % of cases, urgent biliary decompression is necessary. Biliary decompression may be performed endoscopically or by a percutaneous transhepatic route depending on the level of obstruction. Elective definitive treatment in stabilized patients involves cholecystectomy with choledochotomy and CBD exploration .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. This patient's abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and elevated bilirubin level may be consistent with acute hepatitis A. However, in acute hepatitis A, liver enzymes would typically be even higher than in this patient (typically over a thousand). Also, hepatitis A would not account for this patient's dilated common bile duct. Option: B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis could account for this patient's elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, and transaminases. It can also cause a dilation (and strictures) of the common bile duct. However, it usually presents insidiously with signs of cholestasis (e.g., jaundice, pruritus, fatigue) or cirrhosis and not with acute pain seen in this patient. Option: D. The patient's upper abdominal pain, jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and elevated bilirubin levels may be consistent with autoimmune hepatitis. However, autoimmune hepatitis would not explain her dilated common bile duct. Also, the onset of autoimmune hepatitis would be insidious rather than acute.

Extraedge:

A T-tube is left in place for cholangiography and removal of any retained stones. A T-tube cholangiogram is performed on the 7th-10th day postoperatively. If the cholangiogram is normal, the T-tube is removed. However, if a residual stone is discovered, the T-tube should be left in place for 4-6 weeks for the tract to mature. The stones are then removed percutaneously through the matured tract using Burhenne's technique .

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of choledochal cyst
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type l Classification of choledochal cysts. Type I - Fusiform or cystic dilations of the extrahepatic biliary tree, are the most common type, making up > 50% of the choledochal cysts.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Type II, saccular diverticulum of an extrahepatic bile duct. Rare, < 5% of choledochal cysts. Option: C. Type III, bile duct dilatation within the duodenal wall (choledochoceles), makes up about 5% of choledochal cysts. Types IVa and IVb, multiple cysts, make up 5% to 10% of choledochal cysts. Type IVa affects both extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts, whereas type IVb cysts affect the extrahepatic bile ducts only. Option: D. Type V, intrahepatic biliary cysts, are very rare and makeup 1% of choledochal cysts.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man, with a 6-year history of ulcerative colitis, complains of fluctuating jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and weight loss for the previous 6 months. Plasma alkaline phosphatase is 40 U/L (normal range 30–130 U/L). The anti mitochondrial antibody is negative. Select the likely diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a chronic liver disease caused by progressive inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts of the liver. The inflammation impedes the flow of bile to the gut, which can ultimately lead to liver cirrhosis, liver failure, and liver cancer. The underlying cause of the inflammation is believed to be autoimmunity. There is an association of PSC with ulcerative colitis. The following blood studies may suggest the diagnosis of PSC: Elevated alkaline phosphatase or γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT) Elevated serum transaminase level (but maybe normal) Elevated serum bilirubin level (in advanced stages) Serum albumin and prothrombin time abnormal (with advanced disease) Immunoglobulin IgG and IgM levels elevated in 48 and 80 per cent of cases, respectively The presence of perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibodies (p-ANCAs) in 60–82 per cent of patients Radiological imaging can aid diagnosis: endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP).

Highyeild:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC ) is a rare disease characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. PSC is a progressive disease that can lead to secondary biliary cirrhosis and is commonly associated with other autoimmune diseases, such as ulcerative colitis. The mean age of presentation for PSC is 30 to 45 years , and men are affected twice as often as women. Symptoms of PSC include intermittent jaundice, fatigue, weight loss, pruritus, or abdominal pain. Diagnosis of PSC is confirmed through ERCP revealing multiple dilatations and strictures of the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree. The clinical course of PSC is highly variable, with some patients remaining asymptomatic for years while others progress rapidly, leading to secondary biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Primary biliary cirrhosis - it is autoimmune fibrosis of intrahepatic bile ducts. The most common symptom is fatigue, most specific is pruritus but the anti-mitochondrial antibody is positive in > 95%cases. Option: B. Hepatic metastases is a malignant neoplasm that has spread to the liver from a primary site. Ultrasound and CT scan of the abdomen will confirm the diagnosis. Option: C. Cholangiocarcinoma - malignancy of biliary tree. The patient has obstructive jaundice like the picture so alkaline phosphatase should be raised.

Extraedge:

Cholangiocarcinoma is a potential complication of PSC, and patients need to be monitored regularly. There is no known curative treatment for PSC, and medical management is largely supportive. Surgical management with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has produced reasonable results in patients with extrahepatic and bifurcation strictures. In patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only option, offering excellent results with overall 5-year survival as high as 85%.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has a 2-month history of increasing generalized fatigue and severe pruritus. He has hypertension and ulcerative colitis which was diagnosed via colonoscopy 5 years ago. Current medications include lisinopril and rectal mesalamine. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), his pulse is 86/min, and his blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and multiple scratch marks on the trunk and extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show Abdominal ultrasound shows thickening of the bile ducts and focal bile duct dilatation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Solution:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis In contrast to other autoimmune hepatobiliary diseases, primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is more frequent in men. Although in earlier stages it is usually asymptomatic, patients in the later stages present with pruritus, jaundice, elevated parameters of cholestasis, and wall thickening and irregular diameter of the bile duct on ultrasound. PSC is classically associated with ulcerative colitis.

The clinical course of PSC is highly variable, with some patients remaining asymptomatic for years while others progress rapidly, leading to secondary biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) has an insidious onset in most patients but can also present with fatigue, scleral icterus, and increased transaminases as seen in this patient. AIH mostly affects women and frequently presents with positive antinuclear antibodies, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient. Option: C. Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) presents with fatigue, pruritus, and increased cholestasis parameters (ALP, conjugated bilirubin) as seen in this patient. PBC is also associated with other autoimmune diseases including ulcerative colitis. However, PBC mostly affects women and presents with positive antimitochondrial antibodies in > 95% of cases, which this patient does not have. Option: D. Hepatitis B in its acute form is asymptomatic in most patients but may cause fatigue which lasts for a few weeks. It may also cause mildly elevated transaminases, as seen in this patient. The patient's sexual history also puts him at increased risk of HBV infection. However, hepatitis B does not cause thickening of the bile ducts and focal bile duct dilatation on ultrasound, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes into the emergency department because of nausea and severe pain in his upper abdomen and right shoulder blade for the past day. He was able to eat a little for breakfast but vomited up the meal a couple of hours later. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), his pulse is 124/min, and his blood pressure is 92/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant with soft crepitus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant shows a Gall bladder with an air-filled, thickened wall and no stones in the lumen. Laboratory studies are given below.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic pancreatitis with pseudo cyst rupture

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Emphysematous cholecystitis The crepitus in the abdominal wall and thickened Gall bladder with gas strongly suggest emphysematous cholecystitis as the most likely cause of this patient's abdominal (and referred scapula) pain and shock (fever with unstable vitals). Patients with this form of cholecystitis are classically elderly men with diabetes. Infection of the Gall bladder with gas-forming bacteria requires emergency cholecystectomy, as delays in curative treatment are associated with gangrene and Gall bladder perforation.

Highyeild:

Emphysematous cholecystitis Emphysematous cholecystitis begins with acute cholecystitis, which can be caused by gallstones or occur without them. Ischemia or gangrene of the Gall bladder wall and subsequent infection by gas-producing organisms follow acute cholecystitis. Emphysematous cholecystitis is more common in elderly men and patients with diabetes mellitus. Gallstones are present in many cases of emphysematous cholecystitis. Anaerobes such as welchii or Cl. perfringens and aerobes such as E. coli are the main causative organisms. Clinical features of emphysematous cholecystitis are similar to those of nongaseous cholecystitis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The rupture of pseudocysts can result in intraperitoneal bleeding and even shock, which are seen in this patient, but the lack of free intra-abdominal fluid on ultrasound allows this diagnosis to be ruled out. Abdominal pain associated with chronic pancreatitis would also radiate to the back, but not the scapula. Option: C. Gallstone ileus occurs when a gallstone passes through a biliary-enteric fistula and becomes impacted in the ileum. It also manifests with abdominal pain, nausea, fever, and leukocytosis. Abdominal CT , which is the imaging modality of choice for gallstone ileus, should reveal Gall bladder wall thickening and air in the biliary duct, but the air in the Gall bladder wall itself is not consistent with gallstone ileus. Option: D. A perforated duodenal ulcer should be considered in a patient with suspected or known peptic ulcer disease (PUD) who experiences a sudden exacerbation of abdominal pain. This patient, however, does not have PUD or any sudden, sharp, and severe abdominal pain that would suggest acute perforation. Furthermore, perforation of the duodenum would not explain why the Gall bladder wall is thickened and filled with air.

Extraedge:

Prompt surgical drainage combined with appropriate antibiotics is necessary for treatment. Cholecystectomy is the best treatment for complicated acute cholecystitis. Percutaneous cholecystostomy under local anaesthesia can be performed to drain the Gall bladder in unstable patients. The morbidity and mortality rates associated with emphysematous cholecystitis are considerable.

questions.text: According to Tokyo consensus guidelines for severity grading of acute cholecystitis. The following features come under: Serum creatinine >2.0 Platelet count <1,00,000/mm3 PT-INR > 1.5 PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300 Select the correct answer from give below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade III Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for severity grading of acute cholecystitis: Grade III (severe) acute cholecystitis: Associated with dysfunction of any one of the following organs/systems: Cardiovascular dysfunction-Hypertension requiring treatment with dopamine ≤5µg/kg/min, or any dose of norepinephrine (noradrenaline) Neurological dysfunction-Decreased level of consciousness.
